headline.main: BAR CONVENTION RITUALS: TALK, DRINKS, MORE TALK

results.snippet: In the course of the American Bar Association's convention, Ernest T. Guy did not lack for work.   Before the convention ended Wednesday, Mr. Guy, the bar association's director of meetings, supervised more than 1,200 events: speeches and panel...
results.lead_paragraph: In the course of the American Bar Association's convention, Ernest T. Guy did not lack for work. Before the convention ended Wednesday, Mr. Guy, the bar association's director of meetings, supervised more than 1,200 events: speeches and panel discussions, prayer breakfasts, luncheon meetings and dinner dances, golf tournaments and tours of antebellum Atlanta. He and his staff made nearly 600,000 ''impressions,'' such as photocopies, signs, tickets, in their own print shop, shipped from the bar group's Chicago headquarters in trailers. The trucks imported some 59 tons of materials, most of it paper. ''The printed document,'' he explained, ''is very important to lawyers.''

results.snippet: They re-created Gower Champion's dances onstage and they reminisced about him offstage at a party Wednesday at the Red Parrot. It was a benefit to aid the Gower Champion Dance Fund, which will preserve on tape the shows shaped by the legendary...
results.lead_paragraph: They re-created Gower Champion's dances onstage and they reminisced about him offstage at a party Wednesday at the Red Parrot. It was a benefit to aid the Gower Champion Dance Fund, which will preserve on tape the shows shaped by the legendary director-choreographer who died on the day his show ''42d Street'' opened. The tribute, which exuded sentiment without melancholy, was the inspiration of Danny Carroll, who plays the choreographer in the show. ''When you do somebody's work eight times a week for three years,'' Mr. Carroll explained, ''you feel that some old-fashioned love for that person should be spread around.''

results.snippet: This year marks the 300th anniversary of German settlement in America. It was on Oct. 6, 1683 that 13 Mennonite families, 33 people in all, from the city of Krefeld arrived in Philadelphia and founded Germantown, Pa. And thanks to the German-...
results.lead_paragraph: This year marks the 300th anniversary of German settlement in America. It was on Oct. 6, 1683 that 13 Mennonite families, 33 people in all, from the city of Krefeld arrived in Philadelphia and founded Germantown, Pa. And thanks to the German- American Tricentennial Commission the event is not about to go unnoticed. The commission's goal is to encourage and coordinate the many activities and observances taking place throughout the country this year. It was established by President Reagan, who has also designated 1983 as the Tricentennial Anniversary Year of German Settlement in America. Commission members include Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice of the United States, and Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency.

headline.main: CONVICTED KILLER DEFENDS 'REVOLUTIONARY' ACTS AT U.S. BRINK'S TRIAL

results.snippet: A man serving a life sentence for killing a police officer testified as a defense witness yesterday in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan and defended ''clandestine revolutionary work.''   The witness, Sundiata Acoli, was questioned by Sekou...
results.lead_paragraph: A man serving a life sentence for killing a police officer testified as a defense witness yesterday in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan and defended ''clandestine revolutionary work.'' The witness, Sundiata Acoli, was questioned by Sekou Odinga, a defendant acting as his own lawyer in the 19- week-old trial in Federal District Court. The testimony sought to portray Mr. Odinga as a revolutionary rather than a criminal. ''There is definitely a war going on in this country,'' Mr. Acoli said, contending that the war began when black people were brought here as slaves.

headline.main: ARMS CURB DEBATE SETS GLENN APART FROM RIVALS

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

results.snippet: The debate on nuclear arms control has been one of this year's longest-playing records here but, because it has been stuck mostly in the groove of exchanges between Congress and the Reagan Administration, the differences between the leading...
results.lead_paragraph: The debate on nuclear arms control has been one of this year's longest-playing records here but, because it has been stuck mostly in the groove of exchanges between Congress and the Reagan Administration, the differences between the leading candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination have never clearly emerged. In Iowa Saturday, where the word ''survivability'' is in the vocabulary of both farmers and arms control activists, a ''peace forum'' in the Des Moines Civic Center drew out some of the differences, some subtle and some not, between the four candidates who participated: former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senators John Glenn of Ohio, Alan Cranston of California and Gary Hart of Colorado. All four attacked President Reagan's arms control policies and endorsed a nuclear freeze, less military spending and the scrapping of some major new weapons systems, including the MX intercontinental missile. However, by the end of the two-and- a-half-hour question-and-answer session enough differences, mostly in tone and emphasis, had emerged to set Senator Glenn apart from the rest of the field and placed him about where his political strategists want him to be: committed to arms control reductions but more pro-military than the three other candidates on the panel.

headline.main: AT THE RANCH, REST AND TOUGH QUESTIONS FOR '84

results.snippet: On the fifth day, President Reagan rested from the uncertain labors of his undeclared re-election campaign.   Here, amid the lush mix of blue sky, shaded mountain and pristine beach, it is entirely believable that the cares of tomorrow must wait,...
results.lead_paragraph: On the fifth day, President Reagan rested from the uncertain labors of his undeclared re-election campaign. Here, amid the lush mix of blue sky, shaded mountain and pristine beach, it is entirely believable that the cares of tomorrow must wait, re- election strategy included, as the President labors on his own piece of the American dream, to quote the oratory that flowed so easily last weekend. Taking up the comforts of his beloved ranch in the California chaparral, the President turned to the business of digging post holes for a new fence. He left his strategists to ponder the rougher work of his undeclared campaign, made clear in the previous rather exhaustive four days on the road.

headline.main: SOVIET ASTRONAUT RECORDS HARDSHIPS OF LONG FLIGHT

results.snippet: Excerpts from a diary kept by a Soviet astronaut during a seven-month flight last year have given an unusually candid glimpse into the fatigue and anxieties experienced by crewmen living for long periods in space.   Diary extracts published this...
results.lead_paragraph: Excerpts from a diary kept by a Soviet astronaut during a seven-month flight last year have given an unusually candid glimpse into the fatigue and anxieties experienced by crewmen living for long periods in space. Diary extracts published this week in Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, showed that the astronaut, Valentin M. Lebedev, frequently had trouble sleeping during his record-setting 211- day flight. He also fretted about relations with fellow crewmen, about separation from his family and about the increasing tedium of the 3,300-orbit mission, and worried about what officials on the ground thought of his work. The diary also contained some mild grumbling about the quality of processed foods aboard the spacecraft, the Salyut 7 orbital laboratory.

headline.main: EARLY BOOK-FILM TIE-IN FOR 'THE RIGHT STUFF'

results.snippet: The Ladd Company's movie version of ''The Right Stuff'' will reach theaters late in October. Bantam's movie tie- in edition of Tom Wolfe's book about the original astronauts is being shipped to bookstores this week, an extremely unusual two months...
results.lead_paragraph: The Ladd Company's movie version of ''The Right Stuff'' will reach theaters late in October. Bantam's movie tie- in edition of Tom Wolfe's book about the original astronauts is being shipped to bookstores this week, an extremely unusual two months early. Normally, a novelization of a movie, or a reissue of the original book with a cover depicting the movie's stars, trails after the movie. William Kotzwinkle's novelization of ''E.T.'' and the various novelizations and illustrated storybooks of ''Return of the Jedi'' were swept onto best- seller lists by the success of the films.

results.snippet: The United States was disappointed by Yuri V. Andropov's latest arms control statement, a senior Administration official said, because it did not show any flexibility on two of the key issues delaying progress in negotiations on limiting...
results.lead_paragraph: The United States was disappointed by Yuri V. Andropov's latest arms control statement, a senior Administration official said, because it did not show any flexibility on two of the key issues delaying progress in negotiations on limiting medium-range missiles in Europe. The official said the Soviet leader's statement ignored two basic problems: Mr. Andropov's insistence that no new American missiles should be deployed by the Western alliance, and the renewed American insistence that any agreement on limits on the Soviet SS-20 mobile missile system be applied to Asia as well as Europe. (Page 1, Column 1.)

headline.main: BEHIND EACH ASTRONAUT STAND THE 'OTHER' WOMEN OF NASA

results.snippet: HOUSTON SALLY RIDE broke a major sexual barrier with her space shuttle flight in June, entering a world once reserved for male test pilots and scientists.  But some feel the hoopla over her achievement has obscured the need for more ground-level...
results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON SALLY RIDE broke a major sexual barrier with her space shuttle flight in June, entering a world once reserved for male test pilots and scientists. But some feel the hoopla over her achievement has obscured the need for more ground-level action at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The next shuttle flight, scheduled for Tuesday, will mark a milestone in space for another American minority group - blacks - as Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr., a Philadelphia-born Air Force combat and test pilot, is sent aloft. While most eyes are on Challenger and its crew, however, observers of the launch should be able to pick out a few women among the men of mission control here at the Johnson Space Center.

results.snippet: The countdown began this afternoon for the next space shuttle mission, one that will include a nighttime launching and landing, the deployment of a satellite for India, tests of a new air-to- ground communication system and a black astronaut.  ...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The countdown began this afternoon for the next space shuttle mission, one that will include a nighttime launching and landing, the deployment of a satellite for India, tests of a new air-to- ground communication system and a black astronaut. The five astronauts who will fly the space shuttle Challenger arrived here this morning for final briefings before the flight. Officials of the Kennedy Space Center said preparations were proceeding smoothly toward a scheduled liftoff Tuesday at 2:15 A.M., New York time. Commanding the planned six-day mission, the eighth in the shuttle program and third for the Challenger, will be Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, who was a pilot on the second test flight of the Columbia in 1981. The other crew members will be going into space for the first time. They are Comdr. Daniel C. Brandenstein of the Navy, Lieut. Comdr. Dale A. Gardner of the Navy, Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr. of the Air Force and Dr. William E. Thornton, a physician.

results.snippet: The machines and astronauts, including the first American black selected to fly in space, were reported ready today for the nighttime launching of the space shuttle Challenger early Tuesday.   Preparations at launching pad 39-A proceeded without a...
results.lead_paragraph: The machines and astronauts, including the first American black selected to fly in space, were reported ready today for the nighttime launching of the space shuttle Challenger early Tuesday. Preparations at launching pad 39-A proceeded without a hitch, according to Charles Henschel, the countdown conductor. The weather is expected to be favorable. And the crew members had apparently adjusted their biological clocks to the schedule of working nights and sleeping days that they are to keep through the planned six-day mission.

headline.main: INDIA TO PURSUE DOWN-TO-EARTH GOALS FROM 22,300-MILE ORBIT

results.snippet: Soon after the space shuttle Challenger rockets into orbit Tuesday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., if all goes as planned, the craft's computers will be ordered to bring to powered life its most important piece of cargo: Insat 1-B, India's...
results.lead_paragraph: Soon after the space shuttle Challenger rockets into orbit Tuesday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., if all goes as planned, the craft's computers will be ordered to bring to powered life its most important piece of cargo: Insat 1-B, India's one-of-a-kind earth satellite, which combines telecommunications, weather forecasting and television- broadcasting functions in a single package. When Guion S. Bluford Jr., a crew member, gives the order, the tension is likely to rise considerably here and at a modern new spacecraft control center at Hassan, a few miles west of here in the Deccan Highlands of southern India. For Insat 1-B is absolutely critical to India's fledgling efforts to apply space science and technology to its very down-to-earth problems. And when the astronaut triggers the flow of numbers to the consoles at Hassan that will tell the state of Insat's health, it will signal the beginning of the end of India's experimental period in space and the start of its operational period. Insat 1-B, says Prof. U. R. Rao, the Indian space research organization's director, ''heralds the dawn of the communications satellite era in India.''

results.snippet: The first black American to soar into space, Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr., has in his career followed a trajectory as sure and graceful as that of the Challenger. Fascinated as a child with things that fly, he pursued his interest to the point...
results.lead_paragraph: The first black American to soar into space, Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr., has in his career followed a trajectory as sure and graceful as that of the Challenger. Fascinated as a child with things that fly, he pursued his interest to the point of taking a doctorate in aerospace engineering. A reluctant hero on the issue of racial barriers, the 40-year-old Air Force officer acknowledged his pioneering role at a recent news conference, but he stressed that he was more excited about being able to fly on the Challenger. He has nonetheless gone out of his way to share with black students his devotion to the art of aerospace engineering.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS BEGIN BUSY SCHEDULE AFTER LIFTOFF TURNS NIGHT INTO DAY

results.snippet: The space shuttle Challenger, lifting off at night in a brilliant spectacle of sight and sound, carried five American astronauts into earth orbit early today. There they began a busy schedule, including the first tests of a $100 million data relay...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Challenger, lifting off at night in a brilliant spectacle of sight and sound, carried five American astronauts into earth orbit early today. There they began a busy schedule, including the first tests of a $100 million data relay satellite that malfunctioned earlier this year. Despite intermittent problems with antennas and ground equipment, the preliminary tests of the improved communications link with the shuttle were described by flight controllers as ''very successful.'' After a sleep period that began at midafternoon, Houston time, the astronauts were awakened at 9:30 P.M. by a recording of the fight song for Georgia Tech, the alma mater of the flight commander, Capt. Richard H. Truly. They prepared for their second busy day in space, with a flight plan calling for them to deploy a communications and weather satellite for India at 3:49 A.M. Wednesday. The satellite, called Insat-1B, is regarded by the Indian Government as critical to research and technological development.

results.snippet: Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, commander of the eighth flight of the space shuttle, will be at the controls of the spacecraft Challenger when it makes the first night shuttle landing Monday, but it will not be the first time he has landed an...
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Richard H. Truly of the Navy, commander of the eighth flight of the space shuttle, will be at the controls of the spacecraft Challenger when it makes the first night shuttle landing Monday, but it will not be the first time he has landed an aircraft in darkness. A naval aviator who has made many landings on a carrier deck in darkness, Captain Truly admits that at first it seemed that landing the 102- ton craft at night might be ''a very difficult thing to do in a safe manner,'' as he put it in an interview. But after many practice runs in a space shuttle simulator, he said the procedure seemed to promise ''what I think is going to be a very routine operation.'' The 45-year-old astronaut, who was born and raised in Mississippi, had little interest in aviation when young. ''I wanted to be a fire truck driver,'' he recalled. ''That seemed like an exciting thing to me when I was a kid and, as a matter of fact, it still does.''
